author: Ryan Ward
title: Draymond Green Admits Heâ€™s Advised Warriors Not To Make Recent Trades
text:
(Photo by Sean M. Haffey/Getty Images)
The Golden State Warriors may have seen their championship window in the Stephen Curry era come to an end this summer, with star guard Klay Thompson choosing to leave the team in NBA free agency to sign with the Dallas Mavericks and seemingly no one giving this team a chance to compete next season and beyond.
Despite the fact that the Warriors wonâ€™t intimidate anyone the way the roster is currently constructed with Draymond Green and Curry leading the way, Golden State has frequently been mentioned in trade rumors to acquire Utah Jazz star Lauri Markkanen.
If the team can acquire Markkanen, the Warriors could become a force to be reckoned with once again in the Western Conference, as theyâ€™d have that third star in the prime of their career and might be able to put something together.
However, it seems as though Green might be pushing back on the team making some deals recently, as he perceived it as something that would hurt the team in the future rather than helping him and Curry compete for a title right now via NBA Central.
â€œThatâ€™s a bad trade, donâ€™t do that trade,â€ Green said.
Draymond Green says the Warriors nearly made short-term trades beneficial to him and Steph but harmful in the long run, and he advised against them
â€œThatâ€™s a bad trade, donâ€™t do that trade.â€
(ğŸ¥ @club520podcast / h/t @ClutchPoints )
pic.twitter.com/r5igSmIvUj
â€” NBACentral (@TheDunkCentral) July 25, 2024
Even though Green seems to be pushing back on a deal Golden State could be working on, the Warriors brass will do what is best for the team and might want to maximize what they have left with Curry running the show in the Bay Area.
Itâ€™ll be interesting to see whether the Warriors are able to acquire Markkanen and if that thrusts them back into the title contender conversation.

author: Yahoo TV UK
title: Flooding on the River Severn & Ouse following Storm Gerrit
text:
SWNS Flooding on the River Severn & Ouse following Storm Gerrit Read full article SWNS 29 December 2023 at 4:29 pm
Pictures show parts of a historic city and town underwater after Storm Gerrit - with flood alerts warning of further chaos to come The images show how the River Severn burst its banks and flooded both Tewkesbury and Worcester - with urgent warnings for residents to take immediate action. The Met Office has also issued a number of severe weather warnings as a cold front sweeps into the UK. Strong winds in the wake of Storm Gerrit are expected from 11am on Saturday (December 30) to 3am on Sunday (New Year's Eve). The storm has already brought significant chaos to much of the UK with further warnings of severe travel disruption and loss of power. The Met Office said: "An active cold front will move east across England and Wales during Saturday and into Sunday and will be characterised by strong winds and some heavy rain. "Gusts of 45-50 mph widely, but squally near the cold front with some gusts around 60 mph, whilst the strongest gusts are likely near coasts in the west and south, with 65-75 mph in places." The expected rain comes alongside the flood warning from the Environment Agency that for the River Severn urging those people to take action now. The warning added: â€œFlooding is forecast to affect locations with low lying land expected to be most affected. â€œWe are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area and we will continue to monitor levels closely. â€œAvoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.â€

Lusa 24 de Outubro de 2024 Ã s 22:36 Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa, Presidente da RepÃºblica FOTO: Mariline Alves O Presidente da RepÃºblica considerou esta quinta-feira legÃ­timo o confronto polÃ­tico sobre questÃµes de seguranÃ§a, na sequÃªncia da morte de um cidadÃ£o baleado pela PSP, e afirmou ser prematuro visitar os bairros afetados por distÃºrbios.

Eu manifesto-me num sentido, manifesto-me noutro sentido. Ã‰ a democracia", acrescentou o Presidente da RepÃºblica em declaraÃ§Ãµes aos jornalistas Ã  margem de uma visita ao Museu do Design, em Lisboa.

Em relaÃ§Ã£o Ã s manifestaÃ§Ãµes agendadas para sÃ¡bado - uma a exigir justiÃ§a pela morte de Odair Moniz e outra agendada pelo Chega em defesa da polÃ­cia - que terminarÃ£o na Assembleia da RepÃºblica, Marcelo afirmou que a "democracia tem desses fenÃ³menos" e que nÃ£o "Ã© a primeira vez que os temos na sociedade portuguesa".

Sem nunca referir diretamente a morte de Odair Moniz, Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa voltou a apelar Ã  pacificaÃ§Ã£o, considerando prioritÃ¡rio nesta altura a "estabilizaÃ§Ã£o" do conjunto de "fenÃ³menos de violÃªncia" que tÃªm marcado os Ãºltimos dias.

O chefe de Estado sublinhou ainda o encontro desta quinta-feira entre o Governo com os autarcas da Ã¡rea metropolitana de Lisboa, que disse significar que "hÃ¡ um acordo entre autarcas e o Estado quanto Ã  importÃ¢ncia de atuar nesta situaÃ§Ã£o".
Esta atuaÃ§Ã£o, defendeu, deve passar pelo reforÃ§o das forÃ§as de seguranÃ§a para que esteja garantida a prontidÃ£o da aÃ§Ã£o e haja tambÃ©m uma "perceÃ§Ã£o da prontidÃ£o" por parte dos cidadÃ£os.
Marcelo acredita que se "retiram algumas liÃ§Ãµes que sÃ£o importantes para o futuro" por parte dos autarcas e do Governo e que este encontro tambÃ©m foi importante para as pessoas "olharem para a prÃ³xima semana e para a seguinte e encontrarem razÃµes para acreditar na seguranÃ§a, na ordem pÃºblica, na tranquilidade e nÃ£o a violÃªncia.

author: VNExplorer
title: Mary Berry's foolproof Victoria cake recipe made her 'fall in love with baking'
text:
National treasure Mary Berry has shared hundreds of delicious and traditional recipes published over the years, but her love of baking began with some of her early baking creations, including her classic Victoria sponge cake recipe.
Mary, 88, revived her classic recipe and showed her legion of fans how they too can make the baking delight for friends and family, or even themselves. Thankfully, the recipe that holds a dear place in Maryâ€™s heart isnâ€™t complicated and is perfect for first-time bakers.
Famed for being a judge on The Great British Bake Off, Mary has published more than 70 cookery books over the past five decades. She began her career in the food and drink industry back in the 60s, becoming the cookery editor of Housewife magazine, followed by Ideal Home magazine.
Sharing a fond memory of the time she taught others to make the Victoria Sponge Cake, the 88-year-old TV personality said: â€œFor my first job for the Electricity Board, I would visit people in their homes and teach them how to use their ovens by cooking this fabulous cake. The all-in-one method makes it one of the simplest cakes to make. I feel it is the most healing of cakes to make, too.â€
Mary is a big fan of the cake
Mary revealed she used to teach people how to make the fabulous concoction. The simple recipe follows an all-in-one method, which means you wonâ€™t need to separate ingredients as they can be added into one mixing bowl.
You can bake your perfect Victoria sponge in a breeze, as it takes half an hour to prepare in the kitchen. Hereâ€™s the step-by-step guide.
Ingredients: 225g (8oz) of self-raising flour 225g (8oz) of caster sugar 225g (8oz) of cold butter or baking spread, plus extra for greasing Four eggs One teaspoon of baking powder Topping and filling: 300g (Â½ pint) of whipped double cream One jar of strawberry jam (370g or half a cup) Caster sugar for dusting Instructions: Preheat the oven to 180C (350F), 160C (320F) for a fan oven or Gas Mark 4. Grease your cake tins and line them with baking paper. Place the cake ingredients into a large mixing bowl and stir for around two minutes until you have a smooth and light cake batter. Divide the cake batter in half and pour it evenly into the two cake tins. Use a knife to smooth out the cake batter on top. Bake in the oven for around 25 minutes or until the cake has risen and is golden brown in colour. Leave the cakes to cool in the cake tins for a few minutes. Once they have rested, run a knife around the edge to loosen them and take them out of the tins. Set them aside on a wire rack if you own one and leave them to fully cool. In a bowl, whisk the cream until it is fully whipped. Then decide which cake should be on the top and spread jam on the bottom. For the cakeâ€™s bottom, carefully spread the whipped cream on top. Place the cakes together so that the jam side is touching the cream side. Dust the top of the cake with sugar, and then your classic Victoria sponge cake is ready to serve. Do you have a story to sell? Get in touch with us at [email protected] .

author: fijivillage
title: Edward Snow's successful fruitful venture
text: Fruit farmer Edward Snow from Savulu Estate in Ra has thrived in agriculture by utilising resources around him to earn a living by planting guavas and dragon fruits and also providing jobs for the community. While speaking to fijivillage News, Snow says despite the hardships brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic, his family continued to thrive and was almost unaffected by its impact. He says by the end of last year, they started harvesting more than 750 guava trees and 990 dragon fruits, and it has been supplied to outlets such as Grace Road, New World Supermarket and other outlets around Fiji. The villager thanked the Taiwan Technical Mission based in Naucubonu in Sigatoka and the Agriculture Ministry for their timely assistance in providing seedlings for them to pursue their business. Snow says the dry season is a challenge for them, therefore, they have been waiting for assistance from the Agriculture Ministry to provide them with a borehole, but for the time being, they have been using water tanks to water their farm. He adds that i-Taukeis have a lot of resources with the availability of land but lack the knowledge on how to utilise it. He further says this year, they plan to extend their farm and provide more job opportunities to the villagers. Stay tuned for the latest news on our radio stations

author: The Pillar
title: 'Simple but not simplistic': On the road with the Eucharistic Revival's test pilgrims
text: Editorâ€™s note: This report was originally published June 13, 2023. Weâ€™re republishing it during the week of Christmas 2023, for your reading enjoyment! On a June morning outside Albion, Indiana, a sporty blue Audi TT hit the brakes hard on a hilly country road, the carâ€™s driver befuddled by a spectacle in the roadâ€™s shoulder. With his car at a dead stop in the middle of the road, his foot still on the brake, the driver rolled down the window and called out: â€œWhat are you all doing? Is this some kinda parade?â€ Hereâ€™s what he saw outside of his car: A line of pedestrians, walking alongside a newly planted cornfield. At the front was a young woman in a blue T-shirt, wearing a floppy-brimmed hat and consulting a map. Behind her, another young woman, carrying a large crucifix on a pole. Behind them was a man in a white tunic â€” an alb â€” and a stole, who was carrying in front of him a large, golden statue of some kind, with a kind of a sunburst design. That group was followed by a half dozen or so more â€” some young, some old â€” most carrying prayer beads, and reciting Hail Marys, one after another. If the driver had looked closer, he would have seen in the center of the golden statue â€” formally called a monstrance â€” a small glass case, which appeared to contain a thin, white wafer of bread. All this ceremony for that? Apparently so. The driver called out again: â€œWhat are you all doing?â€ Most of the crew kept walking. But one of the walkers, a young man in his early 20s, leaned into the car window: â€œThis is a Eucharistic pilgrimage.â€ â€œWhat does that mean?â€ â€œThe Catholic Church has the Eucharist, which we believe is the body and blood of Jesus.â€ The driver frowned and chewed his lip. It wasnâ€™t clear how much all that meant to him. But the next bit impressed him enough: â€œWeâ€™re walking from Fort Wayne to South Bend. Itâ€™ll take a couple of days more, and while we walk we prâ€”â€ The driver cut him off. â€œSouth Bend! Geez! Thatâ€™s far! Good luck!â€ The window rolled up, and the Audi sped off. The walkers continued on their trek, finishing the sorrowful mysteries of the rosary, before offering a litany of the saints. â€” On that Indiana road outside Albion, the Catholics walking up and down hills were the first Eucharistic pilgrims of the National Eucharistic Congress, which will be held next July in Indianapolis, as a countrywide gathering of Catholics, convened to adore Christ in the Blessed Sacrament. The Congress will be preceded next year by four walking Eucharistic pilgrimages, in which teams of 12 young people â€” with a priest â€” will traverse the country, from the East Coast, the Bay Area, the headwaters of the Mississippi, and the southern tip of Texas, along the countryâ€™s border with Mexico. Walking for weeks â€” and carrying the Eucharist across the country â€” those teams will converge in Indianapolis ahead of the July 17 Eucharistic Congress in Lucas Oil Stadium. Along the way, teams will be housed and fed by local parishes and host families, and Catholics from across the country will be invited to walk alongside them. Planning the Eucharistic pilgrimages is a massive undertaking, mostly coordinated by the staff at [Modern Catholic Pilgrim ](https://www.moderncatholicpilgrim.com/)â€” a non-profit pilgrimage apostolate with the contract for arranging those 2024 Eucharistic pilgrimages. The group is already arranging housing and volunteers, and securing permits for solemn processions in the larger cities through which theyâ€™ll pass. But a pilgrimage canâ€™t be planned without on-the-ground experience, staff members at Modern Catholic Pilgrim told The Pillar â€” especially since Eucharistic pilgrimages, traveling with the Blessed Sacrament, are somewhat rare, and require a lot of forethought. So to get a sense of how things will go, planners started working last October with the Diocese of Fort Wayne-South Bend, Indiana, to plan a 2023 walking Eucharistic pilgrimage for Fort Wayne, in the dioceseâ€™s southeast, to South Bend, in its northwest. The walk would be kind of a tune-up for the 2024 pilgrimages â€” a proof of concept, really â€” and it would give pilgrims a chance to start praying for those 2024 walks, organizers figured. And, according to Will Peterson, Modern Catholic Pilgrimâ€™s executive director, the team learned a lot in their eight-day trek across a sliver of Indiana. â€” The groupâ€™s plan to walk from Fort Wayne to South Bend was simple. Each day, beginning June 4, theyâ€™d walk from parish to parish across the diocese, ending at St. Matthewâ€™s co-Cathedral on June 11. In total, the route would be about 100 miles, an average of 12 or so miles for each of their eight days. Each evening theyâ€™d have adoration or evening prayer in a parish church, and then be hosted by local families. The team for that Indiana pilgrimage would be led by Peterson, 31, of Modern Catholic Pilgrim. With him would be four other â€œperpetual pilgrims,â€ making up a kind of core team: John Donahue, a documentary filmmaker from Florida; Lauren Rivera, an undergraduate at Notre Dame; Bridget Breckler, who plans to enter a Carmelite monastery in the fall, and [Fr. Stephen Felicichia](https://todayscatholic.org/vocation-call-answered-by-felicichia/), a Fort Wayne-South Bend priest ordained three years ago â€” who had special care of the Eucharist as the group made their trek. As the group walked, theyâ€™d be followed by a support vehicle, driven either by Peterson or a parish volunteer. Local Catholics would join them each morning for Mass, followed on most days by a one-mile solemn procession, with a canopy, altar servers, and incense. The solemn processions would walk through small towns â€” sometimes with police escorts â€” and end on courthouse lawns or in park pavilions, where parishioners had set up small altars for a few minutes of adoration. After those solemn processions, and after a Eucharistic benediction at the terminus, the servers and most of the parishioners would disperse, heading for coffee or breakfast at small-town diners. But the perpetual pilgrims would put on more sunscreen and have some water, and the group would set out on a â€œsimple procession,â€ walking with a map reader and a crucifix-bearer at the fore, Fr. Felicichia carrying the monstrance, and the rest of the team walking behind, along with the locals who had decided to accompany them for more miles that day. As they walked, the team would pray the rosary â€” 20 decades daily â€” along with Divine Mercy chaplets, and other pious devotions. Theyâ€™d sing Marian songs and ancient Eucharistic hymns. Further back from the monstrance, pilgrims and local Catholics would chat a bit, sometimes casually, and sometimes in deep spiritual conversation. And at times a silence would seem to fall over the whole group. Theyâ€™d walk quietly, listening to the buzzing of insects, and the drone of crop-spraying airplanes overhead. In front yards or on porches along the route, devout Catholics would drop to their knees as the Eucharist passed by â€” others along the road would stare slack-jawed, or start recording with their phones. Sometimes a dog would follow for a few minutes, or a horse would trot alongside the walkers behind a pasture fence. Only a few people would ask what the group was doing â€” far fewer than youâ€™d expect, actually. But when it would happen, one of the pilgrims would stop to chat, and then jog to catch up with the group. Except for lunch, the group would almost never stop walking, unless for a traffic light, or to cross a busy intersection. â€” While some daysâ€™ walks were 10 miles or fewer, others were more of a push, and on one, the team walked almost 20 miles from one parish to the next. It isnâ€™t easy to carry a gold-plated monstrance for even 10 miles each day. But Fr. Felicichia, 37, explained to The Pillar that he had a few advantages: First, his experience as a West Point grad, with two Army tours in Afghanistan, had gotten him accustomed to long walks with heavy equipment. Second, the monstrance used by the team was lightweight. Most important, though, is that Felicichia walked with a kind of custom harness over his alb, fitted with a pouch of sorts across his chest, into which the base of the monstrance could be fitted. That spread the weight of the monstrance from his arms to his back and chest â€” and the same kind of harness will be used by the priests accompanying each of the pilgrimage teams next year. Peterson told The Pillar that the liturgical protocols for the â€œsimple processionâ€ were developed by a team of consultants for the Eucharistic Congress, and had gotten a sign-off from the liturgy office of the USCCB. When the group did stop during the day â€” at lunch, or before the simple processions began â€” Felicichia said heâ€™d been instructed to repose the Blessed Sacrament in a small wooden tabernacle affixed to the inside of the support SUV. Felicichia would only repose the Eucharist in that tabernacle for short periods, the priest said. When the Eucharist was in that temporary tabernacle, the priest never seemed to leave its side. When he needed to make a bathroom break, another perpetual pilgrim stayed with the Eucharist. â€œWe never leave the car alone if the Lord is here,â€ the priest told The Pillar. â€œNot ever.â€ Each night heâ€™d reserve the host in the tabernacle of the parish the pilgrimage team was visiting, Felicichia told The Pillar. Felicichia said that while it took a bit of getting used to, he was comfortable with the liturgical protocols of the â€œsimple procession,â€ which were specifically approved for the Indiana walk by his own Bishop Kevin Rhoades of Fort Wayne-South Bend. The priest, with a military bearing his fellow pilgrims described as â€œhardcore,â€ told The Pillar that he believed planners had given careful consideration to the logistical prospects of traversing the country with the Blessed Sacrament. â€œTo the best of my ability, it is as reverent as you can make it. How reverent? Well, weâ€™re walking on roads and adapting to things on the fly. And in that sense, it does remind me a lot of the Army. So you adapt â€” obviously, there are certain things you canâ€™t do and certain things you can, because youâ€™re carrying the God of the universe with you.â€ The priest said that at times, while carrying the monstrance, heâ€™d been in uncomfortable situations â€” heâ€™d tried to maintain a silent disposition, and someone had come up to him to chat, or heâ€™d needed to apply more sunscreen to his head, as he was not willing to wear a hat while carrying the Blessed Sacrament. â€œI have had moments of half-a-second of, like, â€˜How should I handle this or that situation,â€™ and then you make a choice, and then you go with it. Itâ€™s all just prudence to the best of our ability,â€ the priest said. â€œWhat is my goal here? My goal isnâ€™t to offend the Lord, my goal is to maintain as much reverence as I can, and Iâ€™m doing the best I can with what I have,â€ he added. â€œReally, It reminds me so much of the Army, where you get the orders, and they say, â€˜We want this, make it happen,â€™ and you say, â€˜Well, I presume I have some flex then as we go.â€™ So weâ€™re flexing, as we figure out how to make a pilgrimage like this, with the Blessed Sacrament, really work.â€ But while the plan was simple, there was still room for it to go awry. During their trek across Indiana, the pilgrims would deal with rain, with an allergic reaction to sunscreen, and with then a broken SUV, which left them scrambling one day for a spare support vehicle, eventually made available by an Albion, Indiana parishioner. For Peterson, the organizer, thatâ€™s part of what it means to make a pilgrimage â€” having a clear sense of where youâ€™re going, and trusting that God has a plan for how youâ€™ll get there. â€œYou need to know where youâ€™re going and what your intentions are,â€ Peterson told The Pillar, as he walked along a farm road on June 7. â€œAnd if you really know that, and youâ€™re holding those things, youâ€™re making a pilgrimage.â€ Peterson told The Pillar that he was learning some practical lessons for the 2024 pilgrimages, especially about better advanced communication with parish planners along the route. But he said that he was mostly encouraged about the grace he saw on the pilgrimages. â€œIâ€™ve seen on this pilgrimage so much trust and courage. You can see in John, and Lauren, and Bridgid, who havenâ€™t done a lot of pilgrimages before this, how much trust they have in Providence, and how much theyâ€™re just all in for this. So thatâ€™s a really encouraging sign for what weâ€™re planning.â€ Still, Peterson said that before it got started, he hadnâ€™t been sure what exactly to expect from this walking Eucharistic pilgrimage. While heâ€™s traveled on dozens of pilgrimages before, he had before never made one in which the Eucharist was present every step of the way. Four days into the walk, Peterson told The Pillar: â€œI have been very impressed with how prayerful itâ€™s been. I had wondered if we could walk for hours and stay engaged like this. From the beginning of planning these national Eucharistic pilgrimages, weâ€™ve been talking about how to maintain reverence in a practical way: How can we respect our Lord, and at the same, build the camaraderie that usually comes as pilgrims are walking together?â€ â€œAnd itâ€™s beautiful to see it happen.â€ â€” The 2024 Eucharistic Congress, and the preceding pilgrimages, are being organized as part of the U.S. bishopsâ€™ conference â€œEucharistic Revivalâ€ â€” a three-year initiative aimed at increasing faith and devotion in the Eucharist among American Catholics. But the revival initiative has not been met with universal support from the U.S. bishops. Some have raised concern about the cost of the Eucharistic Congress â€” budget estimates place the event at some [$14 million](https://www.pillarcatholic.com/p/the-cost-of-communion-is-the-eucharistic-congress-too-expensive). Peterson said that because so much is provided by parish volunteers, the budget for the Eucharistic pilgrimages wonâ€™t require much â€” the pilgrimage costs are staff time spent planning and permitting, the cost of support vehicles, and supplies like first aid kits and T-shirts. Other bishops have said the Eucharistic Revival is the wrong priority for the Church, or has placed [ too much focus on Eucharistic adoration](https://www.pillarcatholic.com/p/eucharistic-pilgrimage-expected-to). But the Church has made much of â€œwalking togetherâ€ in recent years â€” with a focus from Pope Francis on the notion of synodality, the Church has encouraged Catholics to draw together in communion with one another, especially centered around the Eucharist, for prayer, and common discernment, and for a common sense of apostolic mission and identity. John Donahue, 23, one of the eventâ€™s perpetual pilgrims, told The Pillar heâ€™d experienced a prayerful sense of common cause as he traveled with his fellow pilgrims. Definitely. Itâ€™s true.â€ Donahue added that the pilgrimage was changing his perception of his fellow Catholics, in ways that he hadnâ€™t expected â€” and giving him a deeper appreciation for the gifts they offer the Church. â€œOne thing Iâ€™ve noticed is that thereâ€™s not actually a lot of men joining usâ€ for the daily walks, he told The Pillar. â€œItâ€™s been predominantly women in their 50s and 60s.â€ â€œAnd one, thatâ€™s a challenge for me and my brothers, to join them.â€ â€œBut two, thatâ€™s given me a great appreciation for these very, very devout women who live this crazy life of prayer, who sometimes get seen as, like, â€˜Susan from the parish councilâ€™,â€ Donahue said, in reference to the popular meme often satirizing older women involved in parish life. â€œBut itâ€™s like, really, no â€” these are the people whoâ€™ve showed up to follow Jesus today. For his part, Peterson said the pilgrimage planners had tried to focus on keeping the event grassroots, and broadly accessible to as many Catholics as possible. â€œPart of our planning for this was during the time of the [February 2023] Asbury Revival. This is for everybody,â€ he explained. â€œPart of that means weâ€™re trying to make the pilgrimages as accessible as possible â€” you can come to Mass, or you can come to the one-mile solemn procession, or you can come for a couple of miles, or for the whole day. As much as you can.â€ â€œAnd then there are the people who offer us hospitality, which can be transformative. Henri Nouwen put it well, that â€˜if there is any concept worth restoring to its original depth and evocative potential, it is the concept of hospitality.â€™â€ â€œAnd so there are different ways that people can participate, and that way everyone can be a part of pilgrimage. This is for everyone.â€ â€” If the Eucharistic pilgrimages are for everyone, what are they? What purpose do they serve in the Churchâ€™s life? It turns out, there isnâ€™t just one answer. And that might be a part of the spirituality of pilgrimages. Some pilgrims and local Catholics in Indiana told The Pillar that they see the pilgrimages as evangelistic opportunities â€” that the sight of the monstrance might sow seeds of curiosity, which would eventually lead to conversion. They must be in a cult or something.â€™ But even if you think, â€˜Man, thatâ€™s weird,â€™ you can still acknowledge that they have a great faith in what theyâ€™re doing,â€ she added. â€œIt gives us a chance to say: â€˜This is what we believe in and this is who we believe in, and this is who weâ€™re doing it all in.â€™â€ â€” Susan â€” a parishioner at Blessed Sacrament in Albion, Indiana who declined to use her surname â€” walked more than seven miles with the pilgrimage on June 7. She did. â€” Peterson told The Pillar he was not surprised that pilgrims had different reasons for walking along with Blessed Sacrament, or that they expected different fruits.
